bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Philip Alexander Bruce, July 2, 1922

div1.p: Carter maintains that the sanitation of the Isthmus of Panama was Gorgas' work. He credits Reed for laying the foundation of all subsequent yellow fever work.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Philip Alexander Bruce, July 2, 1922
div1.opener:
Please return to
Miss #(3
Bruce
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
, D. C.
July 2, 1922.
/LC
Dr. Philip Alexander Bruce,
University of Virginia, Va.
Dear Doctor Bruce:
div1.p:
Both of your notes received, and I have put off answering you
until Sunday as I am too busy during the week.

1/ I am willing to admit--ir, indeed, assert--that I, myself;
LePrince and others did all we could--and on the whole good work--
in the assistance of Gorgas in the sanitation of the Isthmus. It
was primarily his job, however.

2/ You have, I think, misunderstood this part of my note. Un-
questionably, our work in Panama--and, indeed, all work for the elimi-
nation of yellow fever since--has been based on Reed's discovery.
We received from him not a "cue, but a foundation for work. What I
said was that my research work “had determined the direction” of
Reed's--gave him his “cue” so to speak.

Few scientific discoveries--medical or otherwise--are in their
entirety the work of any one man: He who puts the capstone on the
completed structure gets--as he should--the credit for it, but the
foundation and walls may--and generally--have been built by many
hands.

Reed, for instance, had the knowledge of the discovery by Ross
of the conveyance of malaria from man to man by the Anopheles mos-
quito: Of Bignami's demonstration that a period of 8 to 10 days was
was
2.
required for the developement of the malaria parasite in this mos-
quito--prior to the end of which time after becoming infected she
was not capable of conveying infection: Of my demonstration that “when
a case of yellow fever developes in a clean, but infectable environ-
ment, the environment becomes infected at once--within a few hours--
but does not become infective--that is, capable of infecting other men--
for a considerable period”--which I afterwards fixed as “minimally some-
what in excess of 10 days.” The analogy between Bignami's findings and
mine led first Lazear: then Reed: then Durham and Walter Meyer inde-
pendently to the same deduction: That the mechanism of conveyance of
these two diseases--malaria and yellow fever--was the same.

I say “independently” because I have no reason to believe that
Reed had discussed the matter with Lazear before he to me formulated this
opinion, which was on the Fourth of July 1900, when we took breakfast
together at Quemados.

Reed came to Cuba purposing 1/ To investigate the role of the Sana-
relli bacillus and, if this were found negative, 2. to investigate the
intestinal flora in yellow fever. The direction of his investigations
was changed, as he stated, by the consideration of my data. He had
received no directions as to the nature of the research after investi-
gating the Sanarelli bacillus, but suggestions from General Sternberg
were as above and negatived the conveyance by a living host. He quoted
Sternberg as saying: “conveyance of yellow fever by fomites is univer-
sally admitted.”

Does this make the matter plain? I certainly have not meant to
imply that Reed's discovery was not the basis of the yellow fever
yellow fever
3.
work in Panama. It unquestionably was.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, (Signed) H. R. Carter.
